good afternoon everybody and welcome to the Thursday november 8 2012 session in
our series about green technologies and transportation this series is produced
by the u.s. Asia Technology Management Center which is a research center in Stanford School of Engineering and the
first thing I want to do is to thank the Allen minor foundation for series
sponsorship for providing financial support that helps us we'll have some
refreshments outside afterward and you know it's thanks to our sponsor that we have that I also want to say a special
thanks today to Nixon Peabody which is a law office a major law firm for
especially helping us to arrange this session today our speaker is coming all
the way from Wuhan China and Nixon Peabody was my first introduction to mr.
pink and I'd like to recognize mr. Joseph Bach who is with Nixon Peabody
and hope you can say hi to Joseph who has done a lot of great us-china work in
regard to this kind of corporate issues so today we're going to talk about
marine transportation and marine transportation is actually missed a lot
when people are thinking about greenhouse gases and global warming but
right now probably from air transportation and also marine
transportation almost four percent of all of the carbon dioxide emissions in
the world is coming from that source however if they don't do something about
it this percentage is predicted to increase to like seventy two percent by the year twenty thirty just because it's
being cut back so up many other places and also there's an awful lot more transport than there used to be so I've
got a few slides to sort of introduce this whole issue
the real issue when it comes to marine transportation is bunker oil and almost
all commercial ships are using marine diesel engines these are very different
kinds of engines than you find in an automobile or in a big truck they are
made to use this kind of oil that's called bunker oil and bunker oil is a
high sulfur product of the crude oil refining process basically you always
get it when you're trying to make gasoline and so on and so forth so it
will be produced no matter whether it's used or not but it has a very high
sulfur content compared to other kinds of oil is average according to the
International Maritime Organization is for bunker oil to have two point seven percent sulphur by weight in the fuel
that equals about 27,000 parts per million the diesel fuel that you use in
a car has about 50 parts per million so 50 vs 27,000 is a pretty big difference
in terms of how much sulfur there is um so one thing about it is since its
produced and it comes out and kind of large quantities from the refining process it's cheap and it's very
important to the whole kind of transportation of goods and services across the world that shipping costs are
low and one major reason that we've been able to preserve low shipping costs is
that these big engines use bunker fuel but it is a source of four kinds of air
pollution sulfur dioxide or sulfur oxide oxide plural nitrogen oxides plural also
particulate matter which is another word for suit and thus it also contains some
sulfur in it and so forth but when you really are smelling diesel fuel somewhere it's the suit that tends to be
the source of to the smell the other kind of thing is it does produce co2 so it's a source of
four major types of air pollution just in regard to sulfur itself sulfur oxides
the European Union which has been pretty active in this and as you can imagine look at the sulfur oxide emissions from
the 25 European nations in the EU total and that's dropping like a rock
meanwhile this steady rise in sulfur oxide emissions from ships is eventually
going to pass the emissions from land-based all across the European Union
somewhere around twenty fifteen or twenty sixteen they've got a similar graph for nitrogen oxides too so this is
an issue so this means that the United Nations got involved it is something
that you can't deal with from the laws of any one country and the UN first
passed the International Convention for the Prevention of pollution from ships
in 1973 and that was revised in 1978 and
the laws that people most care about are the mark hall and x6 which first was
adopted in 97 and it took them until it took them eight years to really bring it into force so the Marple annex limits
that main air pollutants from ships it also prohibits deliberate emissions of
ozone-depleting compounds regulates shipboard incineration you can't just
burn things on ships and it also regulates the emission of volatile
organic compounds from tankers so what's happened in this whole world is that in
2008 they got together again and decided they needed a much more stringent set of
protocols so the new Marple annex that has really just started going into
effect from 2010 has stepped down targets that you
may not exceed and be in compliance with your air pollutions so with regard to
sulfur which is one of the biggest things here the current state of the art was four
point five percent sulphur by weight as a percentage of the emissions coming out
of oven of a ship from the beginning of
this year they're supposed to be at three point five percent and the target
by 2020 is 0.5 percent that's a pretty massive reduction in sulfur there's a
big distinction here they have what are called emission control areas and
emission control areas are the areas that are susceptible to the most damage from marine-based air pollution the
entire Baltic Sea most of the North Sea a lot of the coastal waters around the
United States are in these emissions control areas so in the emissions
control areas it's even more severe this means that you have to either run on a separate set of engines or take really
different kinds of approaches to reducing the amount of emissions oh this
was a concern by the people who put together this set of protocols because
at the time they were thinking it could only be handled through better quality fuel and so there is a provision that if
they don't have enough fuel to run the protocols as it is they will delay the
introduction of the step down so there is a similar set of regulations for
nitrogen oxides today we're primarily going to be talking about sulfur oxides
because that's actually the key to the problem oh you can solve this problem in
several ways our presentation today is about seawater scrubbing of the
emissions from these big marine diesel engines another alternative would be to
use lower sulfur fuel but the only way you can get lower sulfur fuel is through
greater refining and that has an energy it also creates its own kind of sets of
environmental problems to reduce remove sulfur from crude oil and finally you're
going to get this bunker fuel type stuff anyway what are you going to do with it there's even been proposals to take it
and put it back in old depleted oil wells but they're not sure what would happen over the lifetime of the other
thing so another option is to use some sort of an onshore desulphurization
technique for the emissions themselves in coal-fired power plants this is where
you get most of this stuff right now what they have that's an alternative to seawater is to essentially use limestone
or chalk and the chemical reaction is going to yield gypsum which is uh what

of calcium carbonate so it's what happens in seawater is a fascinating
thing sulfur in seawater the sea is actually the natural source of most of
the sulfur in the world and when you have sulfur that runs off of the land
into the ocean microorganisms methylate it and create these dimethyl sulfide and
some of those evaporate back into the clouds and actually helped form the
